content: Irrigation has been crucial for the development and economy of the United States, especially in settling the West and revitalizing agriculture after the Dust Bowl. Technological advancements have modernized irrigated agriculture, but come with costs like infrastructure, federal programs, and potential impacts on water users and the environment. Key measurements of irrigation include water withdrawals and consumption. The primary measurements of irrigation water use are water withdrawals and consumption. Irrigation withdrawals in the United States have decreased by 23% since 1980, with a 9% drop nationally from 2005 to 2010. It is uncertain if the decline in withdrawals has led to a decrease in water consumption due to improved irrigation efficiency. Since 1980, irrigation withdrawals in the United States have decreased by 23%, with a 9% drop nationally from 2005 to 2010. The decline in withdrawals may not necessarily lead to reduced water consumption due to improved irrigation efficiency. Changes in irrigated land vary by region, with only four western states seeing an increase since 2003. Eastern states like Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Mississippi, South Carolina, and Tennessee have significantly increased irrigated acres by 50% since the 1980s, shifting from gravity irrigation to pressurized sprinklers and microirrigation. Since the 1980s, seven states (Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Mississippi, South Carolina, and Tennessee) increased irrigation by 50%, shifting to pressurized sprinklers and microirrigation. In the West, irrigated land increased by 1.7 million acres while applied irrigation water decreased by 1.37 million acre-feet. There has been a decline in water application since 1998, with groundwater withdrawals increasing by 740,000 AF. Since 1998, irrigation withdrawals from on-farm surface water and water delivered to farms in the West have decreased, while groundwater withdrawals have increased. Irrigation withdrawals remain highest in the western-most portions of the United States. In the East, irrigated land has grown significantly since 1984, primarily relying on groundwater withdrawals. This increase in irrigated acres in the East is attributed to factors such as increased commodity prices, drought episodes, and low-cost access to groundwater. Irrigation withdrawals in eastern states have increased by 4.3 million AF since 2003, mainly due to factors like higher commodity prices, droughts, and easy access to groundwater. This has led to a rise in irrigated acres but has also caused a decline in aquifer levels and raised environmental concerns. Irrigation efficiency is defined as the percentage of applied water that is beneficially used and not lost, influenced by factors like system performance, water application uniformity, and crop response to irrigation. Efficient irrigation systems are influenced by factors like evapotranspiration rates, climate conditions, and water conveyance systems. While efficient systems aim to leave additional water in the hydrological system for downstream use, studies have shown that they may lead to greater water consumption in some cases. Efficient irrigation systems aim to maintain crop production levels while conserving water for downstream use. However, some studies suggest that increasing water conservation subsidies for drip irrigation may lead to higher water consumption and crop yield. The efficiency of microirrigation compared to gravity irrigation is debated, with gravity irrigation typically consuming less water due to water return through runoff and deep percolation. Efficient irrigation systems may not always result in less water consumed overall, as gravity irrigation typically consumes less water than microirrigation. Water not taken in by plants through evapotranspiration in gravity irrigation can be returned to surface or groundwater sources. Additionally, adopting more-efficient irrigation technologies may lead to growing more profitable, water-intensive crops. Adopting efficient irrigation technologies may not always reduce overall water consumption. Irrigation systems are classified into pressure and gravity systems, with precision technologies enhancing efficiency. Best management practices focus on improved water management on farms, including conveyance and scheduling methods. Best management practices (BMPs) for irrigation involve improved water management on farms, including conveyance, scheduling, and application methods. These practices are based on select practices identified by USDA's Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) and can apply to both pressure and gravity irrigation systems. Pressure systems pump water through tubing or pipes for application through sprinklers or microirrigation systems. Pressure systems pump water through tubing or pipes to apply water to crops using sprinkler or microirrigation systems. Sprinkler irrigation uses high- to medium-pressure systems to create artificial precipitation, while microirrigation applies water directly to the root zone of crops. Pressure irrigation systems make up roughly 58-65% of irrigation systems in the US, including center pivot, linear move tower, solid set, slide roll, big gun, hand move, and drip systems. These systems are more efficient than gravity systems and can be used to grow most crops. Linear move tower, solid set, slide roll, wheel move, big gun, traveler, hand move, and drip, trickle, or low-flow micro sprinklers are pressure irrigation systems that are more efficient than gravity systems. They require intentional preparation to manage water application for appropriate soil moisture levels, reduce soil erosion, maximize plant growth, lower energy consumption, and increase water efficiency. These systems may include various irrigation Best Management Practices (BMPs) such as microirrigation, sprinkler irrigation, ditch lining, land leveling, and tailwater recovery. Sprinkler systems like center pivot, side roll, and linear move tower irrigation are common types of pressure irrigation systems. This enhances standard center pivot systems to low-energy precision application (LEPA) irrigation systems. LEPA irrigation systems are more efficient than sprinkler and gravity systems as they apply water directly to the root zone of crops. Gravity systems divert water to flood over a crop area through land-forming measures, while controlled flooding methods increase efficiencies. Uncontrolled flooding, the simplest form of irrigation, is less efficient. Irrigation methods like basin, border, and furrow irrigation use land-forming measures to increase efficiencies. Gravity systems are generally less efficient than pressure systems and are suited for close-growing crops like rice. The cost of developing a water supply, including drilling wells and operating pumps, is a significant consideration for agricultural producers when choosing an irrigation system. Groundwater supply development costs, influenced by pumping depth and energy costs, are generally higher than surface water supply costs. Therefore, areas heavily reliant on groundwater tend to adopt high-efficiency pressure systems, while areas with ample surface water resources are more likely to use gravity irrigation due to lower water development expenses. Areas heavily reliant on groundwater tend to adopt high-efficiency pressure irrigation systems, while areas with adequate surface water supplies are less likely to use efficient irrigation systems due to lower water development costs. Irrigation system adoption is also influenced by the type of crop being grown, with perennial tree crops better suited for drip irrigation systems to prevent fruit decay. Close-growing crops like rice typically require gravity irrigation, while widely spaced field crops may not benefit from total field soil saturation. Drip and surface irrigation are more effective in windy conditions, while sprinkler irrigation in arid climates leads to high evaporation levels. Soil type and crop evapotranspiration rates also influence the choice of irrigation system. Soil salinity issues can result from irrigation. Soil type plays a role in selecting the appropriate irrigation method, with sandy soils requiring sprinkler or microirrigation, and clay soils being ideal for gravity irrigation. The labor-technology trade-off between pressure and gravity systems is important when selecting an irrigation method. Gravity irrigation is labor-intensive but requires fewer technological inputs, while automated sprinkler and drip systems need technical knowledge and less labor. Water quality and quantity, including sediment-heavy water, can limit irrigation choices. Salinity and selenium concerns can be managed better with sprinkler or drip irrigation. Between 2009 and 2014, $564 million out of $1.2 billion in funding went towards sprinkler and microirrigation systems. States in the West, particularly California and Texas, received the highest funding amounts, with some southeastern states also in the top 10 recipients.
